title: Right Conductive Hearing Loss with History of Cholesteatoma
chief_complaint: I've noticed greater difficulty hearing recently and I am interested in amplification options. I don't have any trouble hearing out of my left ear.

problem_summary.onset: Childhood history of otitis media; recent notice of increased difficulty.
problem_summary.course: Recurrent otitis media, followed by cholesteatoma and surgery (tympanoplasty).
problem_summary.functional_impact: Greater difficulty hearing in daily life.

history.present_illness: The patient reports noticing greater difficulty hearing recently. He denies hearing loss in the left ear.
history.otologic_history: Recurrent otitis media in the right ear since childhood. Developed a cholesteatoma in the right ear canal which was surgically removed. Underwent a tympanoplasty to repair the right tympanic membrane.
history.prior_management: Surgical removal of cholesteatoma and tympanoplasty in the right ear.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear shows moderately severe conductive hearing loss in low frequencies, improving to mild-moderate in mid-frequencies, and sloping to moderately severe in high frequencies. Left ear thresholds are within normal limits.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear SRT indicates moderate loss, consistent with PTA. Word recognition is excellent (100%) when amplified. Left ear speech results are normal.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear not tested due to previous surgery. Left ear shows a hypercompliant (Type Ad) tympanogram.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Could not be measured in the left ear due to artifact from the hypercompliant tympanic membrane.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a unilateral, moderately severe conductive hearing loss in the right ear and normal hearing in the left ear. The right ear demonstrates a significant air-bone gap but excellent word recognition ability at suprathreshold levels, indicating an intact cochlea but a disruption in the sound conduction mechanism (consistent with history of surgery/cholesteatoma). The left ear is normal audiometrically but exhibits a hypercompliant tympanic membrane.
counseling_points: Your right ear has a 'conductive' hearing loss, meaning the inner ear nerve is working well (as shown by your bone conduction scores), but sound isn't getting through the middle ear system efficiently.
Because your nerve function is good, your ability to understand speech is excellent (100%) when we make the sound loud enough.
Your left ear has normal hearing, though the eardrum is very flexible (hypercompliant), likely just a physiological variance.
Since the hearing loss is conductive and the nerve is healthy, you are a good candidate for amplification, such as a traditional hearing aid or a bone-anchored hearing solution.
notes_for_actor: Portray a patient who is accustomed to having ear issues on the right side since childhood.
You are not in pain, but you are frustrated by the recent increase in hearing difficulty.
You rely heavily on your left ear.
